title: DBMS_CA5_Q1
content: Which DCL command is used to provide a user with privileges to perform actions on the database?

title: DBMS_CA5_Q2
content: What command would you use to remove specific privileges from a user in SQL?

title: DBMS_CA5_Q3
content: Which of the following is a DCL command?

title: DBMS_CA5_Q4
content: Which method is used to prevent SQL injection attacks?

choices.content: Using prepared statements with parameterized queries

title: DBMS_CA5_Q5
content: Which of the following is NOT a form of database authentication?

title: DBMS_CA5_Q6
content: What is the primary purpose of encrypting sensitive data in a database?

choices.content: To protect data from unauthorized access

title: DBMS_CA5_Q7
content: Which SQL clause can be exploited in an SQL injection attack?

title: DBMS_CA5_Q8
content: Which of the following helps to secure database connections?

title: DBMS_CA5_Q9
content: Which of the following describes a functional dependency?

choices.content: A constraint between two attributes such that one attribute uniquely determines another
A method of indexing in SQL

title: DBMS_CA5_Q10
content: What is the main purpose of Armstrong's axioms in the context of functional dependencies?

choices.content: To provide a set of rules for inferring all functional dependencies
To specify the types of joins
To describe the syntax of SQL commands

title: DBMS_CA5_Q11
content: Which type of functional dependency occurs when an attribute is functionally dependent on part of a composite key?

title: DBMS_CA5_Q12
content: What is an example of a transitive dependency?

choices.content: If A -> B and B -> C, then A -> C
If A -> B, then B -> A
If A -> B, then B -> C
If A -> B and C -> D, then A -> D

title: DBMS_CA5_Q13
content: Which SQL query will list all privileges granted to a user named 'john'?

title: DBMS_CA5_Q14
content: What type of dependency must be removed to convert a relation to Second Normal Form (2NF)?

title: DBMS_CA5_Q15
content: How does one ensure that sensitive data in transit is protected from interception and tampering?

choices.content: By using encryption protocols such as TLS

title: DBMS_CA5_Q17
content: If a user attempts to access a database without proper authentication, which type of security threat is this an example of?

title: DBMS_CA5_Q18
content: Which functional dependency is represented by a relationship where an attribute depends on another attribute through a third attribute?

title: DBMS_CA5_Q19
content: Which of the following is a requirement for a table to be in First Normal Form (1NF)?

choices.content: The table must have duplicate rows.
The table must have no transitive dependencies.
All values in the table must be atomic (indivisible).
The table must have a single candidate key.

title: DBMS_CA5_Q20
content: A table is in Second Normal Form (2NF) if it is in 1NF and which additional condition is met?

choices.content: It has a single candidate key.

title: DBMS_CA5_Q21
content: Which of the following describes a table in Third Normal Form (3NF)?

choices.content: It is in 2NF and has no transitive dependencies.
It is in 1NF and has no partial dependencies.
It is in 2NF and has a single candidate key.
It is in 1NF and has a composite key.

title: DBMS_CA5_Q22
content: What is the main condition for a table to be in Boyce-Codd Normal Form (BCNF)?

choices.content: It is in 3NF and every determinant is a candidate key.
It is in 2NF and has no transitive dependencies.
It is in 1NF and has a single candidate key.

title: DBMS_CA5_Q23
content: Which of the following conditions must be met for a table to be in Fourth Normal Form (4NF)?

choices.content: It is in BCNF and has no multivalued dependencies.
It is in 3NF and has no transitive dependencies.
It is in 2NF and has no partial dependencies.
It is in 1NF and has no composite keys.

title: DBMS_CA5_Q24
content: For a table to be in Fifth Normal Form (5NF), which condition must it satisfy?

choices.content: It must be in 4NF and all join dependencies must be implied by candidate keys.
It must be in 3NF and have no partial dependencies.
It must be in 2NF and have a single candidate key.
It must be in BCNF and have no transitive dependencies.

title: DBMS_CA5_Q25
content: Given a table Students with columns StudentID, Name, CourseID, and CourseName, which column(s) would you remove to achieve 2NF?

title: DBMS_CA5_Q26
content: Consider a table Employees with columns EmployeeID, EmployeeName, DepartmentID, and DepartmentName. How can you normalize this table to 3NF?

choices.content: Create two tables: one for Employees and one for Departments.
Create a composite key using EmployeeID and DepartmentID.
Keep the table as it is.

title: DBMS_CA5_Q27
content: Which SQL command would you use to create a new table for normalizing the Employees table into 2NF?

choices.content: CREATE TABLE Departments (DepartmentID INT PRIMARY KEY, DepartmentName VARCHAR(255));
CREATE TABLE Employees (EmployeeID INT PRIMARY KEY, EmployeeName VARCHAR(255));
CREATE TABLE Employees (EmployeeID INT, DepartmentID INT);
ALTER TABLE Employees DROP COLUMN DepartmentName;

title: DBMS_CA5_Q28
content: What does partial dependency mean in the context of database normalization?

choices.content: A non-key attribute depends on only part of a composite key.
A non-key attribute depends on the entire primary key.
A non-key attribute depends on another non-key attribute.
A non-key attribute does not depend on any key.

title: DBMS_CA5_Q29
content: Which of the following tables is in BCNF?

choices.content: A table with composite keys where all non-key attributes are functionally dependent on the entire key.
A table with a single candidate key and no repeating groups.
A table with multiple candidate keys where some non-key attributes depend on part of a composite key.
A table where every determinant is a candidate key and there are no partial dependencies.

title: DBMS_CA5_Q30
content: Given a table Projects(ProjectID, EmployeeID, ProjectName, EmployeeName), how would you normalize this table to 3NF?

choices.content: Split into two tables: Projects(ProjectID, ProjectName) and Employees(EmployeeID, EmployeeName).
Create a composite key with ProjectID and EmployeeID.
Keep the table as it is.

title: DBMS_CA5_Q31
content: Which of the following conditions indicates a table is in 4NF?

choices.content: It is in BCNF and has no multivalued dependencies.
It is in 2NF and has no partial dependencies.
It has a single candidate key.

title: DBMS_CA5_Q32
content: In the context of normalization, what is a multivalued dependency?

choices.content: A situation where one attribute in a table uniquely determines another attribute.
A situation where an attribute can have multiple values independent of other attributes.
A situation where a non-key attribute depends on another non-key attribute.
A situation where all attributes are functionally dependent on the primary key.

title: DBMS_CA5_Q33
content: Which SQL statement would be used to create a table that resolves a multivalued dependency for an attribute PhoneNumbers in a Customers table?

choices.content: CREATE TABLE CustomerPhones (CustomerID INT, PhoneNumber VARCHAR(255));
ALTER TABLE Customers ADD PhoneNumber VARCHAR(255);
DELETE FROM Customers WHERE PhoneNumber IS NULL;

title: DBMS_CA5_Q34
content: To achieve 5NF, which of the following must be ensured?

choices.content: The table must be in 4NF and all join dependencies must be implied by candidate keys.
The table must be in BCNF and have no transitive dependencies.
The table must be in 2NF and have no partial dependencies.
The table must be in 1NF and have a single candidate key.

title: DBMS_CA5_Q35
content: Which SQL query would you use to split a Sales table into Products and Orders tables for normalization?

choices.content: CREATE TABLE Products (ProductID INT, ProductName VARCHAR(255)); CREATE TABLE Orders (OrderID INT, ProductID INT);
CREATE TABLE Products (ProductID INT, OrderID INT);
ALTER TABLE Sales DROP COLUMN OrderID;

title: DBMS_CA5_Q36
content: What is the purpose of normalization in a relational database?

choices.content: To reduce data redundancy and improve data integrity.

title: DBMS_CA5_Q37
content: What is the primary purpose of denormalization in a database?

choices.content: To improve query performance by reducing the number of joins.

title: DBMS_CA5_Q38
content: In which scenario is denormalization most beneficial?

choices.content: When the database has many complex queries involving multiple joins
When the database is small and simple.
When data integrity is the highest priority.
When the database is used for archival purposes only.

title: DBMS_CA5_Q39
content: Which of the following is a common technique used in denormalization?

title: DBMS_CA5_Q40
content: What is a potential downside of denormalization?

choices.content: Increased storage requirements and potential data anomalies

title: DBMS_CA5_Q41
content: What does serializability ensure in a DBMS?

choices.content: That all transactions are executed one after the other.
That concurrent transactions result in a database state that could be obtained if transactions were executed serially.
That no two transactions can occur at the same time.

title: DBMS_CA5_Q42
content: Which type of schedule is guaranteed to be serializable?

title: DBMS_CA5_Q43
content: Consider the transactions T1 and T2. T1 reads and writes on A. T2 reads and writes on B. Are these transactions conflict serializable?

choices.content: Yes, because they do not access the same data items.
No, because they are accessing different data items.
Yes, because they are accessing the same data items.
No, because serializability cannot be determined with this information.

title: DBMS_CA5_Q44
content: What is a dirty read in the context of transaction management?

choices.content: Reading uncommitted data from another transaction.
Reading committed data from another transaction.
Writing uncommitted data to the database
Writing committed data to the database

title: DBMS_CA5_Q45
content: What is the primary goal of database recovery techniques?

choices.content: To ensure data consistency and integrity after a failure

title: DBMS_CA5_Q46
content: Which of the following is a common method used for database recovery?

title: DBMS_CA5_Q47
content: What is the purpose of a transaction log in database recovery?

choices.content: To improve the speed of query execution.
To keep a record of all transactions for recovery purposes.
To reduce the amount of storage used by the database.

title: DBMS_CA5_Q48
content: What does the term 'checkpoint' refer to in the context of database recovery?

choices.content: A point in time when the database is backed up
A point in time when all transactions are committed to the database
A point in time when the database system writes all in-memory changes to the disk
A point in time when the database is restored from a backup

title: DBMS_CA5_Q49
content: Which SQL command is used to ensure that all changes made by a transaction are written to the database?

title: DBMS_CA5_Q50
content: If a transaction fails after updating some data, which command can be used to revert the changes made by that transaction?
